claim: Basic VFR weather minimums in Class G airspace below 1200 feet AGL during the day require 1 statute mile visibility and clear of clouds
VFR weather minimums in Class B airspace require 3 statute miles visibility and clear of clouds
In Class E airspace above 10000 feet MSL, VFR minimums require 5 statute miles visibility and 1000 feet below, 1000 feet above, and 1 statute mile horizontal cloud clearance
Special VFR operations in controlled airspace require at least 1 statute mile flight visibility and the aircraft must remain clear of clouds
To act as pilot in command carrying passengers, a pilot must have made 3 takeoffs and landings in the preceding 90 days in an aircraft of the same category, class, and type if required
To carry passengers at night, a pilot must have made 3 takeoffs and 3 full-stop landings to a complete stop during the period 1 hour after sunset to 1 hour before sunrise in the preceding 90 days
An instrument currency requires 6 instrument approaches, holding procedures, and intercepting and tracking courses in the preceding 6 calendar months
Day VFR required instruments and equipment for powered civil aircraft include altimeter, airspeed indicator, magnetic compass, tachometer, and oil pressure gauge
Night VFR operations require all day VFR equipment plus position lights, anti-collision light, landing light if for hire, adequate source of electrical energy, and spare fuses
IFR operations require the day VFR and night VFR instruments plus gyroscopic rate-of-turn, slip-skid, sensitive altimeter, clock, generator, gyroscopic pitch-and-bank, and DME above FL240
Class B airspace requires an ATC clearance to enter and pilots must have at least a private pilot certificate or student pilot endorsement
Class C airspace requires two-way radio communication before entering and an operating altitude-encoding transponder
Class D airspace extends from the surface to 2500 feet AGL and requires two-way radio communication established before entry
A first-class medical certificate is required to exercise privileges of an airline transport pilot and is valid for 6 calendar months for ATPs under age 40 and 12 calendar months for others
A third-class medical certificate for a private pilot is valid for 60 calendar months for pilots under age 40 and 24 calendar months for those age 40 and older
Under BasicMed, a pilot must hold or have held a medical certificate, complete a medical education course every 24 months, and have a physician examination every 48 months
Required aircraft documents remembered by the ARROW acronym: Airworthiness certificate, Registration, Radio station license if required, Operating limitations, Weight and balance data
An airworthiness certificate remains valid as long as the aircraft is maintained in accordance with applicable regulations and the certificate is displayed in the aircraft
Aircraft registration certificates must be renewed every 3 years and must be carried in the aircraft
A pilot must have a valid pilot certificate and medical certificate in their physical possession or readily accessible when acting as pilot in command
A pilot must present their pilot certificate, medical certificate, and photo ID to the FAA, NTSB, or law enforcement upon request
Flight reviews are required every 24 calendar months and must include at least 1 hour of flight training and 1 hour of ground training
Transponder equipped aircraft must operate the transponder with altitude reporting in Class A, B, and C airspace and within 30 nautical miles of Class B primary airports
VFR on top operations are not authorized in Class A airspace which begins at 18000 feet MSL and extends to FL600
Inoperative instruments or equipment must be removed or deactivated and placarded inoperative, with the MEL or MMEL consulted to determine if flight is permitted
